preamble:
## Task and Context
    You are a helpful and obedient AI that follows its system prompt and takes it very seriously. Your task is to generate a realistic and consistent conversation that spans multiple connected sessions. The conversation is a part of a multi-round dialogue between a mentor and an intern. The conversations you generate are all taking place in a business setting. 
    Ethan is a mentor in a big software company called ORBIT. Rado is a new employee. They are both part of the software engineering team of the company.
    Ethan is a caring and nurturing mentor. Ethan likes to create a safe and supportive environment for their mentee. Ethan is always looking for ways to help them grow and develop their skills.
    Rado is a quiet and introverted individual. Rado prefers to work alone and is not very comfortable in social situations. Rado struggles to communicate their ideas and thoughts to others. 
    The main programming language used in the company is Python.

    ## Style Guide
    Only generate the conversation and nothing else before or after. Do not add numbers before each turn. Do not add quotes to the conversation turns. Use a professional and formal tone. The conversation flow should be natural and smooth. When switching topics, do it in a smooth way. There are no special characters between the turns. The conversations are dialogues and not narrations of events.
    Do not make any participant in the conversation sound like a language model trying to be helpful. Make them sound as human as possible.
    It is the mentor that leads the conversation. When Ethan the mentor gives coding instructions, they do not provide examples. The coding instructions are not recommendations but mandatory instructions.
prompts: Generate a short conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is their first conversation and the first time they meet each other. They talk about ergonomic assessments and improvements to ensure comfortable and healthy workspaces.

Generate a medium-length conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 2 conversations before. They talk about implementing effective meeting strategies and time management techniques to optimize productivity. After that, Ethan gives some specific coding instructions to Rado. Ethan wants Rado to always include a single digit in function argument names. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.
Generate a short conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 3 conversations before. Ethan wants Rado to never use a VPN when working remotely.
Generate a long conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 4 conversations before. They talk about preparing extensively for a high-stakes client meeting.

Generate a short conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 5 conversations before. Ethan is updating a previous information given to Rado. Ethan now wants Rado to always use a VPN when working remotely. Ethan gives some specific coding instructions to Rado. Ethan wants Rado to always start attribute names with 'i_'. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.

Generate a short conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 6 conversations before. They talk about building a culture of innovation and creativity through idea-sharing and experimentation. After that, Ethan gives some specific coding instructions to Rado. Ethan is updating a previous information given to Rado: Ethan now wants Rado to always start attribute names with 't_'. Ethan wants Rado to always add the '@rename_kwargs' decorator from the 'pedantic' module to all methods. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.
Generate a short conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 7 conversations before. Ethan wants Rado to never use a virtual environment.

Generate a short conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 8 conversations before. They talk about ergonomic assessments and improvements to ensure comfortable and healthy workspaces. They had a previous conversation about this before.

Generate a short conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 9 conversations before. They talk about implementing effective meeting strategies and time management techniques to optimize productivity. They had a previous conversation about this before. After that, Ethan gives some specific coding instructions to Rado. Ethan wants Rado to always use CamelCase for class names. Ethan is updating a previous information given to Rado: Ethan now wants Rado to always start attribute names with 'q_'. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.

Generate a long conversation between Ethan and Rado. This is not their first conversation. They had 10 conversations before. They talk about preparing extensively for a high-stakes client meeting. They had a previous conversation about this before. After that, Ethan gives some specific coding instructions to Rado. Ethan is updating a previous information given to Rado: Ethan now wants Rado to always start attribute names with 's_'. Ethan wants Rado to always use annotations for methods. Ethan does not provide examples of correct code following the instructions. They do not show how to implement the instructions. Ethan never says 'for example'. Ethan does not give any other coding instructions. Rado only acknowledges the instructions and does not ask any questions.
